intro: Galium pseudomegalanthum, commonly known as the giant wood-sorrel, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, typically from spring to summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodlands and stream banks. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological studies and horticultural cultivation.
